citations.narrative:
***In the pasture portion of the property, there were at least four cabins that guests rent and spend nights at the facility.
Although there is one person on the property at all times and a camera system, according to the facility representative,
there were no fences or barriers around these cabins to separate humans and animals and no attendant in the immediate
area. There were animals that free roam this pasture creating the potential of public contact. These animals included
Blackbuck, Fallow Deer and Cattle.
Animals left unattended in an area of potential public contact can lead to animal or human injury.
The licensee must ensure that a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be
present at all times during periods of public contact.
To be corrected from August 17, 2023 forward.

***The Asian small-clawed otter enclosure had recently been rebuilt and expanded. The new enclosure butted up against
the perimeter fence, which is only a short distance from the main road around the property. There is no written approval
from the Administrator for this perimeter fence to be less than three feet from the enclosure.
Perimeter fences that are less than three feet from an enclosure can encourage human contact and lead to animal or
human injury.
The licensee must ensure that perimeter fences be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to
prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence and
that such fences less than 3 feet in distance from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator.
To be corrected by October 13, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative on August 14, 2023.
Exit interview was conducted with the licensee on August 16, 2023 via phone.
Additional Inspectors:
CYNTHIA DIGESUALDO, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
